awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH:   Early social experience and epigenetic mediation of adult phenotypes
awd_abstract_narration:
Rodent models, studies of captive primates, and data from human populations indicate that early life experiences have long-lasting effects on health, and that early life experiences and longevity often vary with socioeconomic status. This study utilizes existing data and archived biospecimens from a long-term field study of a gregarious mammal with a social structure permitting comparisons among status classes to assess effects of the early social environment on temperament and fitness. Effects of the early environment to be assessed include quality of maternal care, peer interactions and social status. Available data and specimens permit exploration of relationships among the early social environment, mechanisms of gene expression, circulating stress hormones, individual temperament, and longevity. The methods employed include high-throughput next-generation DNA sequencing techniques, bioinformatics and advanced statistical methods. Broader impacts of this work include a deeper understanding of social and molecular determinants of adverse stress phenotypes. Ultimately, characterization of the early life social factors that shape adult stress phenotypes in free-living, gregarious mammals will facilitate generalization of the research findings to other social species, including our own. In addition to supporting the scientific work above, this project will facilitate a workshop series on research methods and data analysis designed specifically for members of the African Graduate Student Association at Michigan State University.
 
Social experiences early in life have lasting effects on adult temperament and stress phenotype, often through epigenetic modification of genes, and thus patterns of gene expression, that coordinate the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Using data from the MSU Mara Hyena Project, a 28-year study of free-living, gregarious hyenas in Kenya, this proposal will investigate how social factors relate to adverse stress phenotypes, and elucidate the extent to which this relationship is mediated by DNA methylation. Funding from this project will support two research goals. First, this proposal will use Reduced Representation Bisulfite Sequencing (RRBS) to identify differentially methylated regions (DMRs) of the hyena genome that are associated with high vs. low stress phenotypes based on assessment of adult hyena temperament and stress hormones, as well as differences in early social experiences including maternal rank, maternal care, and interactions with clan mates. DMRs that are predictive of the adult stress phenotypes will be identified using Mixed Model Association for Count data via data Augmentation. The second goal is to use mediation analysis to assess whether the identified socially-induced, stress-related epigenetic pathways mediate the effect of early experience on longevity. Findings from this work will improve mechanistic understanding of how social factors affect behavioral and physiological stress phenotypes in an important new animal model. Because a proximate epigenetic mechanism (DNA methylation) is assessed in relation to an ultimate consequence (fitness), this work represents a large step forward in terms of understanding the role of epigenetics in evolution - a concept that has been largely unexplored.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

The overarching aim of this grant was to investigate the extent to which early life social environment influences later life phenotype. We focused on understanding how this phenomenon works by studying molecular mechanism that might link an organism's early experience with its development and biology. We first hypothesized that less maternal care and social connectedness early in life are associated with more adverse adult stress phenotypes, and these associations are mediated by DNA methylation. Second, we hypothesized that development of later life stress phenotypes involves specific molecular pathways linking early social environment with later life stress hormones, identifiable in patterns of differential DNA methylation associated with both sets of variables. To test our first hypothesis, we modeled the extent to which associations between maternal care and social connectedness with later life stress hormones were mediated via global DNA methylation. We found that less maternal care and less social connectedness were both associated with lower global DNA methylation and elevated fecal stress hormones. Using the finer resolution (single nucleotide) genome-wide ERRBS data, we additionally identified stress-related differentially methylated sites that were also predicted by maternal care and that occurred near genes that are known to be involved in immune function and inflammation. Taken together, our results suggest that receiving better maternal care and having more social connections early in life are associated with higher global DNA methylation and lower adult stress; both positive health indicators. We also concluded that associations between maternal care and stress-related differentially methylated CpG sites suggest a role for inflammation pathways in development of adverse adult stress phenotypes.

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to its intellectual merit, this grant also fostered important broader impacts. At the most basic level, this project has provided research funding, facilitated training, and opened doors for professional development opportunities for Z. Laubach. First, the value of the science that was made possible through the support of this grant extends beyond our study system. For example, this work has broadened our mechanistic understanding of how social factors affect development of the stress response, while also providing a tractable framework for future studies to explore similar questions in wild animal populations. Thus, this project provides fodder for a growing interest in understanding how early life social experiences have lasting effects on developing phenotypes and could serve as a critical data point for exploring this phenomenon more generally as possible rule of life. Second, we have taken steps to bridge work in human medical research, namely the Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD), and evolutionary developmental biology. Part of our goal is to identify and understand basic biological processes across taxa, including in biomedical research and also in populations subject to natural selection, with the hopes of fostering cross talk between disciplines and to broaden current views in human public health to include an evolutionary perspective. Furthermore, we have actively disseminated our results to broad audiences through contributions to blogs, including for BEACON, An NSF Center for the Study of Evolution in Action, as well as the Research Spotlight blog hosted by the journal Molecular Ecology. Both outlets have an interdisciplinary audience but are also intended to be accessible to lay public. Finally, our work has provided numerous training opportunities for aspiring young scientist. This project facilitated research experience for 14 undergraduates, many of whom are women with nascent careers in STEM. We also developed and implemented a workshop series on learning to program, clean, and model data in R in collaboration with the African Graduate Student association at Michigan State University.
